posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked: The text has been cleaned and converted into a single paragraph while preserving the core information. Below is the processed content: --- The text begins with the creation of a COTS-compatible belt in-take system designed for a two-stage elevator. It was initially conceived to address the issue of requiring a manual continual elevator with no tube, focusing instead on manufacturing a continuous belt. Initially, the team considered a complex two-slip block system, which involved intricate manufacturing due to the necessity of creating a continuous belt connecting two 3/16" plates. However, after exploring various options, the team decided on a more straightforward approach involving large bearings stacked end-to-end, which simplified the process significantly. This led to the development of a thin-belt example, which proved successful after testing. During development, the focus was on ensuring that the cables were appropriately manufactured, with a strong emphasis on the dimmensional consistency of the components. The team utilized 3D modeling tools like LightWave for visualization and planning, and AutoCAD for drafting purposes. The key constraint was that teams had to build a continuous elevator using no tubes and minimal machinery, which required ingenuity. As the project progressed, the team realized the importance of maintaining a high level of mechanical integrity despite the lack of traditional pulley systems. In the second iteration, the team improved upon their initial designs by introducing a varying pulley size and stage spacing. They created wider examples using larger pulleys and different belt sizes, optimizing the setup for both efficiency and durability. One significant advancement was implementing a positive offset for pulleys, ensuring robust alignment regardless of the belt type. Throughout the development process, the team faced challenges such as drilling precision for pulleys and managing the construction timeline effectively. Despite these hurdles, they successfully completed the project, showcasing the versatility of COTS-compatible systems in modern elevator technology. The final product demonstrates how intricate elevator designs can be achieved through meticulous planning and iterative improvements. The team emphasizes the importance of adhering to specifications while pushing boundaries in creativity and functionality. Overall, the text highlights the journey from initial concept to a refined, reliable elevator solution that balances simplicity with advanced engineering principles.

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked: Elevators can be more effective at lifting objects than robot arms because they don’t move the object further away from the robot while lifting. However, the tradeoff in performance comes with complexity, and often this has kept many teams from using elevators. Price: USD 49.99.

posts.name: pogo
posts.cooked: How long did you take to build it?

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked: This elevator was never built, and this version likely won’t be built either; it was just a fun design idea.

posts.name: pogo
posts.cooked: I see. I'm just trying to get inspirations for the new game.

posts.name: Luke Maxwell
posts.cooked: Fantastic work! We had a similar elevator in our 2024 bot, and the change of the in-carriage holder plates both being on the top and bottom is a great change compared to our design, which had that as a notable shortcoming. the question of this image, how do you keep the nautili tight on the vertical parts? very carefully

posts.name: Andrew Pepmeier
posts.cooked: This is very intriguing, seeing as for many teams, a belt-in-tube setup is beyond their manufacturing capabilities. Have you designed any 3-stage designs that keep the belt-in-tube concept? This could prove useful this season to reach heights. Very impressive design!

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked: These bearing blocks can very easily be put into more tubes to reach another stage. All you have to do is copy the design of the first moving stage again. You also might want to change the bottom belt holder to the other configuration.

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked: Planning an elevator project involves several key components. First, consider the tube plates, which have approximate internal dimensions of 0.06 inches according to REV; slightly oversized tubes may require filing the plates down. Next, tapping requires 48 holes and is time-consuming; alternative options like FabWorks exist but come with added costs. The idler shaft should be either 8mm or 5/16 inches in diameter and cut to 2 inches. For elevator blocks, REV is recommended unless you opt for West Coast Products, which is currently unavailable and expected to restock by January's end. Additionally, use the specified bottom belt holder for belt retention if your elevator isn't the exact width. Lastly, share any issues encountered during construction to help others avoid potential pitfalls.

posts.name: Bailey Beedle
posts.cooked: Hey, I'm trying to figure out where you got the tubing for your idler. I'm working on something similar and having trouble finding the same type of tubing. Maybe it's simpler than I thought? Perhaps using standard steel tubing would work just fine. That might help avoid confusion down the line. I think sticking with something more common could make things easier.

posts.name: Eliot Dunn
posts.cooked:
I would get something like this and cut it to length:(don’t use 6063 tubing!)
https://www.amazon.com/HGYDSER-OD19mm-Aluminum-Diameter-Straight/dp/B0DMDS2QW4?gQT=1&th=1

link_counts.title: Amazon.com: HGYDSER OD19mm 6061 Aluminum Round Tube,outer Diameter 19mm, Inner Diameter 17m 16mm 9mm, Hard Straight Aluminum Pipe(OD19 ID16) : Industrial & Scientific

posts.name: Eren Orhun
posts.cooked: Why not? We usually don't have 6061 aluminum here in Turkey (at least in my region).

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: For this particular item, I agree that 6063 would suffice, although 6061-T6 is generally stronger. You might consider a nearby alloy similar in strength to 6061.

posts.name: Ian K
posts.cooked: The team has just finished building a slightly modified version of this lift to use at our 3 off-season events this year, and it works great! We also took some inspiration from 8744, who added thin polycarb 'rails' for the bearing blocks to prevent any stages from slipping off or coming loose.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Lakeshore FIRST Robotics FRC Activities Director, FRC 4531 Lead Mentor

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
Important - Do not output anything but the cleaned version (no introduction, no little explanation), just the cleaned paragraph.
The text is:

Interesting elevator! I like the blue!


Is that about 3.5 pounds of polycarb for the rails? I'm sure a comp bot would get a WHOLE lot of pocketing.

posts.name: Ian K
posts.cooked: Thanks! I am not sure of the exact weight of the polycarb, but it has already proven to be absolutely worth it. Definitely would add pocketing wherever possible for an in-season robot, although we are still well within weight limit, with 5-10 lbs to spare after we re-attach our arm/intake.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Lakeshore FIRST Robotics FRC Activities Director, FRC 4531 Lead Mentor

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked: How do the polycarb rails work? It seems they act as a spacer or is that incorrect?

posts.name: Ian K
posts.cooked: They help in maintaining the proper spacing between stages in the lift by physically not allowing the bearings to horizontally move off of the aluminum stage they roll on. Small spacers were added to the REV bearing blocks to accommodate the extra distance the bearings needed to reach and so that the plates can fit! This is the big part we got from 8744 after a couple of discussions with them at our competitions.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Lakeshore FIRST Robotics FRC Activities Director, FRC 4531 Lead Mentor
